poem:
"In the Wake of the Wandering Warbler"

Woods so long drowned,
in clay feet shrouded;
Reserves close down - spring blooms
with no admirers round. 

Sticky quagmire and water puddled,
imprints of a six-month deluge,
alluvial whispers laid bare -
a secret woodland refuge.

Transient as the Cetti's warbler's song,
elusive and explosive,
in these solo woods we belong,
the resilience of nature, conclusive.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Country diary: Explosive but elusive, what a bird the Cetti’s warbler is | Derek Niemann So many woods have had feet of drowned clay for so long. Even now, some Wildlife Trust reserves are closed to visitors, spring flowering with no one to see it. Every sticky wood is a little quag, a lot of mire. In our nearest woodland, the six-month flood has largely sunk into the more permeable alluvial silt, leaving a puddled". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
